title: Kennen's Electrical Surge v. Twisted Fate's Stacked Deck
body:
Specifically, the passive portion of Kennen's W, Electrical Surge, and Twisted Fate's E, Stacked Deck.

Both passive states that after X auto-attacks, the next auto will deal bonus magic damage. Simple, and because they're both considered on-hit effects, they should work the same way, right?

Wrong. The differences are so obvious it hurts.

We'll start with their interactions with Dodge, Block, Parry, and Blind.

Twisted Fate - Bonus damage can be Dodged.
Dodging and Blind will not consume the stack.
Block will not prevent the bonus damage, and consumes the stack.
Parry will not prevent the bonus damage, and consumes the stack.

Kennen - Bonus damage CANNOT be Dodged.
Dodging and Blind WILL consume the stack.
Block will not mitigate bonus damage, and consumes the stack. 
Parry negates bonus damage, but still consumes the stack and his passive mark is placed.

Like, really? The only consistency between the two is their interaction with Block. Exactly why do they interact so differently? Oh but it couldn't be THIS b-

Twisted Fate - If the target for his empowered AA is killed before hitting, the stack is not consumed.
Twisted Fate can stack against towers, but the empowered AA is not consumed when attacking towers.
Spell Shields will block ALL damage.

Kennen - If the target for his empowered AA is killed before hitting, the stack IS consumed.
Kennen cannot stack against towers.
Spell Shields will NOT interact with Kennen's empowered AA, therefore NOT mitigating any damage.

...what? Now Twisted Fate's Stacked Deck is functionally better than Kennen's Electrical Surge. Great.

Why do they even function differently? Is there some really, really, really, REALLY vague reason for this?

Or nah?

And don't even get me started on Leona's Q stunning through blind.

replies.body:
Tl;dr Riot has a lot of "on-hit effect" abilities that are inconsistent, despite the use of the same wording. Whether this is intentional or not we won't know.

TF can also kill a minion with an auto and not use up a proc if the base AA damage would kill the minion without the extra damage.

The main issue is that Riot is very inconsistent with these types of abilities, while yes the characters are different they still use similar mechanics and these mechanics should be the same across the board especially when the wording is identical. You also have Shen's Ki Strike, same wording difference mechanics, it can't be blocked by spell shield and isn't applied or used up if the auto attack is blocked or avoided in some way. Ziggs passive is also not blocked by spell shields yet Kha'zix's passive is blocked by spell shield. Sona's Passive messes everything up too, as the bonus damage goes through dodged and parried but can be missed, blocked and spell shielded. Maybe because they are the champions' passive and therefore are different from other spells and that is why they have different interactions but having the exact same wording for any ability that does bonus damage on hit can make it confusing for people when first leaning the game as they are mechanically different.

I think the problem comes from that fact that some of these abilities are spells and not just on-hit effects, the spell portion bypass anything that would stop an auto attack from landing because the auto attack is basically replacing the point and click action of using a single target spell. I think that some of these abilities they are classified as spells because of the fact that they apply additional effects to the target when used such as Leona's stun. Why Kennen's W doesn't get blocked by spell shield is a mystery to me though. Although Sona's passive does not apply a spell effect, according to lolwiki, yet is blocked by spell shield and the bonus damage goes through dodge and parry. Another inconsistency is Udyr's tiger stance DoT application, it will be applied if the target dodges, blocks, or parries the basic attack, however, if Udyr is blinded, the DoT will not be applied AND the spell is used up.
Two words: Spaghetti Code.

I'm primarily using Kennen and Twisted Fate to get at this larger conundrum that you're pointing out. I just figured it would be easier to start off with a smaller post detailing the differences between two abilities rather than going through an extensive list.

Kennen's electrical surge applies as she fires the missile from her.

Twisted Fate's stacked deck applies when the missile hits the target.

Congratulations, Kennen's Electrical Surge passive is an on-hit effect and should be applied when it hits the target just like Twisted Fate's. As of right now, If both Kennen and Twisted Fate were at full stacks and auto-attacked a minion, but the minion died before their projectile hit them, Kennen would lose his passive stacks but not Twisted Fate.

What he's saying is Kennens electrcal surge is applied to the projectile when it leaves kennen. If it misses its wasted. Theres a visual confirming this. TF passive applies when TF successfully hits a target. TF has the buff not the projectile. Theres a visual confirming this.

If you actually looked, you'd see that not only is Kennen's shuriken charged when he has his stacks, but his hand is as well.

Kennen's W passive an on-hit effect, not an on-attack modifier. It should not magically be consumed if his target dies before his basic attack reaches his target.
This isnt DnD breh...each champ has its own phb...
Oh right, you're the guy that thinks Pantheon mains should memorize the hundreds of different ways his passive may or may not get fucked up horribly.

From the wiki:
Aegis Protection does not consistently negate on-hit effects that would be applied with the blocked attack.
On-hit crowd control effects are never blocked.

At least you know crowd control effects are not blocked ie Leona Q or Ren W.

"Aegis Protection does not consistently negate on-hit effects that would be applied with the blocked attack."

"Aegis Protection does not consistently negate on-hit effects"

LOL, NOT ONLY DOES IT HAVE DIFFERENT INTERACTIONS WITH DIFFERENT ON-HITS, IT'S NOT EVEN CONSISTENT.
At least it consistantly does what it's supposed to do. Block a basic attack or turret shot.
Uh, on-hit effects should not apply if the basic attack does not hit. That's kind of the point of being an ON-HIT effect.
Well...I'd argue it does hit. It hits aegis protection consuming the auto attack damage then the on-hit effect applies to Pantheon.

If you're arguing it does hit, then tell that to Ezreal's Mystic Shot. It's on-hit portion will be mitigated by Block.

Or Nidalee's take-down. It's on-hit portion will also be mitigated by Block.

Or Orianna's Clock-work Wind-Up. Her passive on-hit won't apply if Blocked.
I don't understand the point in your reply.  I'm simply telling you WHY the certain interactions happen.

"Kennen's Electrical Surge applies as he fires a missile"

That's implying it's an on-attack modifier, which it isn't. Twisted Fate's Pick A Card is an on-attack modifier, but his Stacked Deck is an on-hit effect. Kennen's passive Electrical Surge is also an on-hit effect. Saying that visuals are the reason for this (which by the way is false, Kennen's hand is also visually charged when at full stacks) is not a good justification for something that is stated to be an on-hit effect to not work like an on-hit effect.

"Kennen's hand is also visually charged when at full stacks"

Twisted Fate's isn't.

That is why they are different.

How can you not understand?

Are you trying to troll, or are you genuinely confused? Because visuals are not the determining factor as to why on-hit effects are inconsistent.

They're both on-hit effects. They shouldn't be different just because "the particles are on Kennen's projectile and hand and not on Twisted Fate's". At that point, they should completely re-define every single on-hit ability by "what it looks like" and not by how it's written out to occur.

You aren't getting it.  It isn't 'because they look different'.  Them looking different is because of the way they work, which I've been trying to explain to  you but you don't want to understand.

When Kennen gets his stacks, his next auto attack will be charged, no matter what.

But _because Twisted Fate's empowered auto attack ONLY hits certain targets_ , it checks it AFTER it has hit the target.

That way it doesn't lose it's proc when it hits a tower.

And the visuals tell a lot more than you'd think they would.

They ARE on-hit effects. They are the supposed to be the SAME mechanically because they are under the same mechanical classification. The fact that they don't is the issue at hand, and it isn't just Kennen and Twisted Fate. This includes champions like Jax and Nidalee that suffer from the same random ass inconsistencies to Pantheon, Fiora, Jax, and Teemo/Quinn.

If they're not both on-hit effects, then they shouldn't look like this:

Kennen - Electrical Surge
Passive: Every 5 attacks, Kennen deals bonus magic damage equal to 40/50/60/70/80% of his attack damage and adds a Mark of the Storm to his target.

Twisted Fate
Passive: Every 4 attacks, Twisted Fate deals an additional 55/80/105/130/155 (+50% Ability Power) Magic Damage.

I mean, really? Those are both on-hit effects, written to the same function, and they barely even resemble each other functionally.

All the visuals tell me is two abilities that are written down to do the same thing don't even come close to doing the same thing.

But it's simple why they don't, they are coded differently.  I understand what you're trying to say, that they SHOULD be the same, but I don't think it matters.

The interactions with other champions seldom happens, you aren't usually going to be using your on-hit affects and be under the influence of a blind at the same time.

This does matter for the sake of consistency. There are a variety of champions that a lone Pantheon could run into, and at this point, he has to memorize an enormous list of different on-hit effects and whether they go through his Block or not.

Kennen and Twisted Fate's on-hits? They go through Block.

Nidale and Ori's on-hits? Nah, they don't get to.

Leona and MF? They get their on-hit bonus damage AND apply their debuffs despite Block because they give sweet f.a. about Pantheon having a passive.

And with regards to Kennen and Twisted Fate, it matters A LOT. Their gameplay rides a lot on their burst patterns, and Kennen especially cares because his stun is heavily tied into just W alone. The fact that a minion dying before my projectiles hits means I suddenly just drop my stun threat and lose significant lane pressure, but Twisted Fate doesn't because he keeps his stack, means a lot to consistent gameplay.

And even if the specific interactions with Jax, Fiora, Quinn, Pantheon, Sivir, Nocturne, Teemo, and Banshee's Veil will rarely happen, they WILL happen, and when they do, gameplay outcome can drastically be affected because some on-hit will still apply, while others won't, and extra points of damage like that can shift entire laning phases and teamfights if utilized well.
Kennen is male

There are a lot of other differences to keep in mind between the two abilities, such as:

-Different attack ranges. Kennen has 50 more range on his auto attack than Twisted Fate, and can therefore proc the effect easier
-Different proc timers. Kennen needs 5 auto attacks to proc, TF only needs 4
-Different scalings. Kennen's scales with AD, TF's scales with AP
-Other effects on the abilities are different. Kennen's W also has an active portion that deals damage to targets in his ult and that have a mark from his passive, TF's only gives some extra attack speed
-Kennen's passive proc also has the benefit of adding a stack of Mark of the Storm to his target, a benefit that TF doesn't really compare with except for his Pick a Card's effects.

You can compare two abilties that are similar, but both need to be compared in the broader context of the champion.

Kennen actually only has a 25 range advantage, since TF has a 525 range, but auto range should NOT determine the functionality of his empowered autos.

Different stack requirements should not change the functionality of the ability, especially when their concept is the same. If Kennen needed 4 and Twisted Fate needed 5, they should still work the same.

Scalings are irrelevant, they both apply as bonus magic damage on-hit.

Kennen's W has an active portion that deals damage to anyone that has a stack of his passive, not just his ult. 

And the ability to stun via your passive because of an empowered auto should not determine the functionality of an ability so much that they only do two things the same: deal bonus damage on-hit and go through Block.

When looking at the functionality of these two abilities, they are presented as being the same concept, with only one requiring an extra stack to apply. The function of two abilities (that at their core are the same) should not be changed simply to balance a champion. The champion should be balanced around the way the ability is MEANT to work. And any distinctions or differences between any abilities such as the two exemplified here should be explicitly stated and have a strong justification, because this drastically affects the gameplay of two abilities that are conceptually meant to be the same.

The concept? "After X basic attacks, the next auto-attack will apply Y bonus damage on-hit." The way this ability works should not change between champions.

Same should hold true for parry and blind, but they do not need the same interactions. As I noted before, the iterations of both Stacked Deck and the passive Electrical Surge as we know them were released within a month of each other in 2010 (Twisted Fate in March and Kennen in April). This isn't just an oversight due to spread release dates, but rather inconsistencies in coding all together.
